awd_titl_txt: Consumer product valuation and interorganizational collaboration and innovation in small manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explain the role that consumer ratings play in how small-scale manufacturing firms choose partners with whom to collaborate and how resultant patterns of collaboration shape an industry over time. Collaboration is an important way for firms to learn from one another and innovate. At the same time, consumers signal approval of innovations through ratings platforms, such as those found on online retail websites. The craft brewing industry is a strategic research site for examining such industry-consumer dynamics in the context of small-scale manufacturing. Interorganizational collaboration is common within this industry. This industry also has a community of consumers who actively rate products on public websites. Like organizations in many industries, small-scale manufactures vary in their strategies for collaborating: some collaborate with many other firms; others with the same firm repeatedly; still others collaborate once and never again. Over time, patterns of interorganizational collaboration structure industries. This project will construct and analyze a dataset from two product rating sites to model the network of collaborations among manufactures in three states in the U.S. Combined with interviews with a random sample of organizational members from the dataset, analyses will show how consumer ratings influence decisions to collaborate among small-scale manufactures and ultimately shape the industry. Findings will bring together and contribute to the literatures on valuation in economic sociology and collaboration in organization science as well as inform managers? strategic decisions regarding collaborations and their prospective outcomes.

 
This project identifies and explains a key mechanism by which industries are structured: the recursive relationship between consumer ratings and interorganizational collaborations. Interorganizational collaboration takes place when organizations cooperate in a non-hierarchical relationship to share knowledge and resources and to innovate in ways that would be too risky to do independently. Status plays an important role in why firms choose certain others with whom to collaborate. Communities of consumers increasingly take advantage of online platforms to rate producers and products, creating an alternative measure of firm and product valuation and status. This project will bring together the literatures on interorganizational collaborations and valuation by determining and explaining the role of consumer ratings in strategic decisions about collaboration. Data for this project will come from a mixed methods study of the small manufacturing industry in three states: California, Colorado, and Illinois between 2009 and 2016. These states have been selected to provide robust samples of collaborations. The time frame reflects the exponential growth in the industry nationally. Quantitative data will come from two rating websites, which will provide evidence of collaborations along with consumer valuations of the products resulting from collaborations. Analyses of this data will provide dynamic network models of the industry as well as concrete measures of status among firms. This data will be supplemented with primary data collected from organizational members in the sample. Investigators will also conduct key informant interviews with a random sample to identify non-measurable features of status and motivations behind choices of collaborators.

por.por_cntn:
This project was designed to understand how, why, and to what ends small manufacturing firms collaborate. We used the case of craft breweries for two reasons. First, craft breweries collaborate frequently compared to firms in other industries. Second, their collaborations yield co-branded products, which allow the researchers to systematically capture data about theses activities.

Researchers conducted quantitative and qualitative research to capture and analyze data about collaborations among craft breweries. Quantitative methods included social network analysis and building databases to capture data about individual organizations in our sample. Social network analysis allows us to understand structure of relationships among firms over time. Organization-level data allows us to understand how certain features of firms, e.g., age, size, and location, play a role in the structure of relationships among them. To collect quantitative data, we drew populations of all craft breweries located in California, Colorado, and Illinois. Our network data captured all collaborations between two or more craft breweries, if at least one of those breweries were located in one of these three states, between 2009 and 2020. This period reflects a time of rapid growth in the number of craft breweries in the United States. Organizational-level data captures demographic data about all firms in each of the three states in our study for the period in question, regardless of whether they collaborated with other firms. Qualitative methods entailed interviews with key staff from a sample of craft breweries in San Diego, Denver, and Chicago. We chose these cities because they had the highest concentration of firms, which afforded insights into the competitive environment faced by firms in our sample. Our sampling strategy also allowed for efficient data collection. Interviews lasted between 45 minutes and two hours. All were recorded and professionally transcribed. We analyzed our network data in R. We used Dedoose to analyze our qualitative data and for mixed-methods analysis.

Early findings show rapid growth in the number of collaborations and collaborators over the decade in question. The number of collaborations among firms grew at a faster rate than the population of firms in each of the states in question, suggesting that collaboration became increasingly common among these small manufacturing firms. This was driven in part because of the growth in the number of potential partners, but mostly due to cultural norms and expectations around collegiality in the industry. We found that craft brewing has a strong culture of collaborating. This was shown formally in our network data and informally in interviews, in which craft brewers reported sharing recipes, techniques, and technical information with one another. The high rates of collaboration took place under increasing competitive forces. As the industry grew, density among firms increased, which resulted in stronger competitive pressures. However, since beer is a non-exclusive good?consumers drinking one brand at time 1 can drink a product from another brand at time 2?competition generally revolved around reputation, status, and access to distribution channels. Reputation and status drove choices of firms with whom craft brewers collaborated. Newer firms sought established firms with whom to collaborate with the hope of a status bump from cobranding with them. Established firms sought collaboration with select newer firms to indicate relevance and trendiness to consumers and existing firms. Over time, the aggregate of collaborations yielded a network with a small number of dense clusters, anchored by older, established firms.
